{\leavevmode\,$\triangleleft$\,\allowbreak}

\AtBeginDocument{\DeclareFontEncoding{T2A}{}{}}

{\begin{list}{}

\title{Welcome to \LyX{}!}
\maketitle
\begin{enumerate}
\item \LyX{} comes with excellent documentation — please use it! Start with
the \textsf{Help\lyxarrow{}Introduction}, which will give you a very
brief introduction to the documentation. Then learn about using \LyX{}
with \textsf{Help\lyxarrow{}Tutorial}.
\end{enumerate}



\subsection{Фраза по русски --- Top N things to know when using \protect\LyX{}}
\begin{itemize}
\item \LyX{} is what we call a {}``document processor.'' By design, it
is different from regular word processors — in a wayhfdjsfhdsвпарвврпарвhgfhd
that makes writing documents easier. But only a little different,
so don't be scared. The documentation will make it all clear.%
\footnote{Have we mentioned yet that you ought to read the documentation?%
}
\end{itemize}

\item Yes, \LyX{} can mimic (almost) all \LaTeX{} functionality. And yes,
\LyX{} can import \LaTeX{} files. Experienced \LaTeX{} users should
skim the rest of the \emph{Tutorial}, then read the {}``\LyX{} for
\LaTeX{} Users'' chapter. (Everyone else: don't worry, you don't
need to know \LaTeX{} to use \LyX{}.)
